results.content:
I quit web development in the first half of the 2000's. Best practices were basically limited to use a doctype so your browser (i.e. IE 5.5/6) wouldn't work in quirksmode, use divs and css instead of tables for the layout, and 'unobtrusive javascript' to make up - read 'polyfill' - for the lack of support of the :hover pseudoclass in IE.

No Gmail, no Ajax, no server-side javascript, no jquery. 

A couple of years ago I decided to start again. 

Alistapart was like quantum physics to me. The talk was all about responsive web design, nodejs, grunt, gulp, angular, git and what not. Greek to me.

Since then, I've tried a zillion courses, but I always seemed to lag behind. As soon as I kinda figured one technology, it was already being superseded by the next. I didn't even grasp 20% of jquery that everybody was talking angular. Then React. And so on.

Then came this course. I thought, okay, let's get back to basics and start all over. 

These guys amazed me. They'll teach you git and how to work with the terminal before you write a line of code. Their focus is on the process of developing more than on the sigle technology.

You'll write a lot of code, there are no lessons where you won't write code actually. But, at the same time, they leave no stone unturned in explaining the hows and whys of every thing they touch upon. 

Highly recommended, for both newbies and old developers that like me can't seem to find a way in the maze that web development has become in the last decade. Kudos.

response.content: Thank you very much for the review.
response.content_html: Thank you very much for the review.

No Gmail, no Ajax, no server-side javascript, no jquery.

You'll write a lot of code, there are no lessons where you won't write code actually. But, at the same time, they leave no stone unturned in explaining the hows and whys of every thing they touch upon.

Highly recommended, for both newbies and old developers that like me can't seem to find a way in the maze that web development has become in the last decade. Kudos.

results.content:
I was liking the bootcamp until I got to the bootstrap section and the instructor started to skip a-lot of steps on how she was completing the website. It was very unclear where the instructor was getting certain information from and the div explanations got a bit lazy. I would recommend this course for those who are already in the field and may be able to keep up a bit better. Not great for beginners looking for thorough explanations. Also, I don't think it's a good idea to not allow students to not be able to leave comments about the course. It will be very misleading for those who are thinking of potentially taking the course.

Thanks for the experience!

response.content: We do not ask students to not leave reviews, we ask students to wait until they get to a certain level as Udemy asks from the very beginning before the course is 10 percent into it. And you got frustrated and mad after you came to us and asked us to give you the answer and we tried to tell you that searching and finding an answer is a big part of development. It is really hard to hand hold students who do not want to study and work for it. Good teachers do not give you answers they teach you how to learn so you can find answers. Good luck in what ever it is you do.
response.content_html: We do not ask students to not leave reviews, we ask students to wait until they get to a certain level as Udemy asks from the very beginning before the course is 10 percent into it. And you got frustrated and mad after you came to us and asked us to give you the answer and we tried to tell you that searching and finding an answer is a big part of development. It is really hard to hand hold students who do not want to study and work for it. Good teachers do not give you answers they teach you how to learn so you can find answers. Good luck in what ever it is you do.
